bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 1, 1902

div1.p: Reed meets Kean. Reed hopes to get to Blue Ridge Summit (Keewaydin)soon. He describes boarding house meals.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 1, 1902
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
May
June 1st.
My precious wifie,
div1.p:
How have
you and the children spent
this beautiful Sunday? I
suppose that you have
rotated from porch
to Summer-houses, and
from the latter to the
porch- I hope that you
have been able to see
the Valley- It has been
a gorgeous day here --
only a little warm in
the Sun- I read the
morning paper leisurely
-- from which I took the
following clippings,
which, I thought, might
interest you -- and then
strolled down to the Army
& Navy Club where I had
lunch with Dr Kean, and
spent several hours
in talking over things
in general- I had ex-
pected to make a call
on Gen. Wood, but the
latter had gone down
the Potomac on a Sail-
As I am anxious to go
to the Summit, tomorrow
to see how my babies
are getting along, I don't
know when I will get
a chance to see him,
but for that matter
it won't make any
difference whether
I see him or not-
of Course, something might
happen to prevent my
getting away tomorrow
afternoon; so don't be
disappointed if I do
not put in an appear-
ance -- although I am
going to try to come,
as I am afraid that
I can't come on Saturday.
My! but Miss Fannie's
Sunday suppers are about
the worst I ever saw!
and such Coffee, after Dug-
dale's! I don't know how
I will ever stand it!
I hate to resolve my-
self into a suffering
Martyyr, every Summer.
Such seems to be my
fate- Tra! la! la!
I hope to have a letter
in the morning- Love
to the girls -- kisses &
love for my precious ba-
bies-
